p: SESR represents a formal elaboration of the idea of human societies as embedded in and as part of ecosystems, forming a “whole” consisting of human social and natural ecological subsystems [ 76]. The integrated human and natural systems that constitute a so-called coupled human-natural system themselves consist of many interacting components, as subsystems of subsystems that make up the “whole.” This perspective and associated body of theory developed in response to environmental and resource problems being perceived as ‘complex systems problems’ which call for more creative forms of collaboration between scientists and society at large (particularly stakeholder groups, or those most affected), involving a broader range of disciplines, skills and participation [ 77].
